title: For any month between and including October 2019 and December 2020, will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 2.0%?
preds:
EU annual inflation down to 0.2% in November - Anadolu Agency
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-annual-inflation-down-to-02-in-november/2080388
Thu, 17 Dec 2020 14:37:54 GMT

The ECB's goal is stability so will seek to maintain inflation below 2%. Inflation hasn't breached the 2% level since April 18 and it has been going down ever since.  With COVID recovery responses by the EU and member states, it will likely see a continued drop or plateau through December.

Getting on this question really late...
- Inflation has been below 2% for the entire period.
- COVID restrictions are tightening around the world.
- GDP expansion is only forecasted at 5% for 2021 which will not accelerate prices.
- Inflation was negative for the past 3 months. 
- Across the euro zone, the highest inflation was 1.6% in Slovakia, followed by 1.2% in the Netherlands and by 1.1% in Austria
-The primary objective of the ECB’s monetary policy is to maintain price stability. The ECB aims at inflation rates of below, but close to, 2% over the medium term

The pandemic has effectively put a cap on inflation for the above period. The negative interest rates, lost employment, government deficits and ECB monetary policy may lead to inflation above 2% in late 2021 or 2022. In the interim, deflation is the more likely outcome of the Covid-19 pandemic.

Overall hard to see an argument for > 0.5% chance that inflation reaches 2% in either of the next 2 months.
- latest Eurostat press release: October inflation was -0.3% https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/10663762/2-30102020-AP-EN.pdf/0a2adb88-41ee-4cfe-ab94-4193d0fb0f42
- ECB September 2020 Macroeconomic Projections show what they expect, and give a story to explain what has happened and their expectations. Most important things (just my impression from skimming this): drop in oil prices, weak demand due to COVID-19 while supply is not too badly affected. https://www.ecb.europa.eu/pub/projections/html/ecb.projections202009_ecbstaff~0940bca288.en.html#toc7

EU: Annual inflation rate at 0.3% in September - Anadolu Agency
https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-annual-inflation-rate-at-03-in-september/2008478
Fri, 16 Oct 2020 07:00:00 GMT

Increasing the montery base is not alone enough for inflation as many people are currently laid off and earn smaller salaries or unemployment benefits. Corona is a deflationary crisis as long as it does not interfere with important supply chains.

The inflation is currently at 0.4 % and driven by falling energy prices due to the Covid-19 pandemic  is heading towards negative territory exacerbated by a second wave of the infection rate. https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/core-inflation-rate  https://www.fxempire.com/macro/euro-area/inflation-rate  https://www.ednh.news/eurozone-inflation-falls-into-negative-territory-unemployment-rises/

Given crowd forecast of 0%, seems little doubt... from the Economist
“The ecb’s own forecasts, released after its monetary-policy meeting on September 10th, show that it is failing. Inflation will rise over the next three years—but only to 1.3%. Financial markets expect it will stay around that level for most of the next decade. Professional forecasters are only a little more optimistic.“

July was 0.4. Looooooooooong way up to 2.0%. Energy prices stable, no other reasons for a big rise in the near future (while it´s a certainty some time in the next few years). https://appsso.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/nui/show.do?dataset=prc_hicp_manr&lang=en

EU disinflationary issues are deeply entrenched and monetary & fiscal policy being over-weighted to(wards) German judgement likely means that it will take longer to see a 2.0% headline yoy inflation print in the EU area, although eventually possible with coordinated fiscal largesse.
Inflation will be huge in 1-10 years. Not so till end of 2020, it will be close to zero till then.

Covid-19 is somewhere completing its initial first wave and entering a second wave, given the spike in infection rates in France, Germany, Spain etc. The deflationary pressures are therefore still in play on the EU economy(s) and as history shows from the 1918-1920 Spanish Flu epidemic there is a potential for four waves of a pandemic.
The European Central Bank (ECB) has taken actions to combat the disruption by using monetary policy to stabilise the financials with an aim of gaining a 2% inflation rate.
The Covid-19 pandemic has resulted in loss in productivity due to social distancing, mass unemployment that decreases incomes that results in a reduction of demand of goods and services. A second wave would prolong the downturn by the postponement of large ticket consumer goods (white goods, cars) and possible investment by companies.
A potential four waves of the pandemic (as experienced by the Spanish Flu) would see a continuation of supply/demand situation through until 2022, that would see a subdued inflation rate for an extended length of time.
https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/key/date/2020/html/ecb.sp200610~a16c903e5c.en.html  https://www.brookings.edu/research/whats-the-ecb-doing-in-response-to-the-covid-19-crisis/  https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/key/date/2020/html/ecb.sp200416~4d6bd9b9c0.en.html  https://www.caixabankresearch.com/en/economics-markets/inflation/impact-covid-19-outbreak-european-inflation  https://voxeu.org/article/real-time-inflation-measurement-during-covid-19  https://voxeu.org/content/will-covid-19-be-followed-inflation-inter-generational-transfer-perspective  https://investors-corner.bnpparibas-am.com/investing/what-will-be-the-impact-of-the-coronavirus-on-inflation/  https://www.ceps.eu/whats-the-ecb-doing-in-response-to-the-covid-19-crisis/  https://www.bruegel.org/2020/05/the-european-central-bank-in-the-covid-19-crisis-whatever-it-takes-within-its-mandate/  https://www.socialeurope.eu/the-covid-19-crisis-inflationary-or-deflationary
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.

The pandemic and the economic depression made it hard to raise the interest rate. Demand is weak and deflation is looming. Countries act toward quantitative easing to push demand but it wont happens if pandemic not over. Earliest prediction of covid vaccine is mid 2021. Therefore small chance for interest rate to hit 2%.
Unless costs of food or something similar suddenly skyrocket the probability that any of the 6 remaining months reach 2% is low.
Meat is going to become more expensive on average, as meat packing industry is likely undergoing some structural (expensive) changes when it comes to organization, employment etc etc
Sorry, it has been plummeting like a rock in a pond. As Europe recovers, it will rise, but not to 2%.
People will not spend the helicopter money they were given. Until coupons are introduced, inflation will stay very low similar to 2009
Down to 0.1 in may. Movements from this low to 2 seem to have taken slightly longer than 7 months in the past fiveteen years.
Depends entirely on the Euro Dollar. If dollar goes down, inflation goes up and vice versa. Every country is fighting to import inflation so the biggest loser wins.... Apparently anyway.

Covid’s economic contraction is more likely to result in deflation. However, should there be an end of year recover with oil prices rising precipitously, it could outweigh deflation in other consumer prices and cause a net positive number. 2% seems very high, but >0 is highly likely

With energy prices rebouncing by up to 100% from their very low in just one month, and airlines offering flights at significantly higher rates due to necessity to distance passengers  and leave capacity in their planes vacant, I see a good share of the HICP composition with steeply rising prices in May/June, while there are hardly any factors left to compensate for that through increasing weight+decreasing price level.
After that, it will certainly happen, perhaps a year or 3 later (and big). But not this year.

For the HICP, the level of economic activity or GDP growth is of no influence, but only the different groups of goods and services with their individual weights which are observed as consumptive expenditures (housing is not considered completely right now). For the total effect on inflation in the second half of 2020, two groups are of outstanding importance: food and essential goods on the one hand, energy (travel) on the other hand and their respective weights in the basket. As one can see from the "flash estimate" for May 2020 https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/272892/272974/Imputation-shares-FE-2020-05/ national bureaus of statistics have already included gross downward changes to the weights of energy, which may further adjust slightly upwards until year's end.  https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/hicp/methodology "COVID-19 and HICP The COVID-19 outbreak in Europe has led governments to impose several measures, such as restrictions in the movement of people and the closure of outlets, which have a direct or indirect impact on household consumption and thus consumer price indices. Eurostat is monitoring the situation in close contact with the National Statistical Institutes (NSIs). Both Eurostat and NSIs are committed to continue the dissemination of HICP data to the best of their abilities." To me, the manifestation of inflation during the time span May to Dec 2020 depends on two major questions:
How fast will the weights of goods and services be adjusted and how realistic will the new weights be? (Will the real drop in travel and mobility find its way into the numbers?)
And, more important: Will the drop in energy prices (at a lower weight) be able to compensate for the price jump in food, basic goods and essentials (at a higher weight) which can be assumed to be a common evidence?
Inflation reaching or exceeding 2.0% in any month till Dec 2020 seems tough at the moment.

> "Money can be exchanged for goods and services"
The Central European Bank may print money so as to weather the crisis, particularly in the later months of this year. This would raise inflation.
covid will force deflationary contraction of all EU economies.
Covid will force contraction and even negative inflation in the eu
Impact of coronavirus on the economy

Unlikely, Eurozone financial leadership is extremely sensitive to inflation and will try to avoid at all cost, but these are special times so never say never and check again after more measures are announced.

a world depression is possible at 9% 
e now haveand a multi-month recession with every Deutsche manufacturer  BMW AUDI MERCEDES and Volswagon Siemens off line. The Tranportation and Visitor Serving Accomodation industries are shut no tourists no busines travel.
Although Bundesrepublik has a generous social welfare system (univeral unemployment and pension) Germany main two banks Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank are plagued with money laundering, non-performing loans.
German consumer especially in Thuringia not going on any shopping tours
put 2 cycles are inflationary Demand exceeds capacity (demand pull) and  Output Costs increase per component.(cost push) While the long run trend is inflation .  Our coinage is a relic of inflation. Pennies are like milles for taxes. Dimes, Quarrers which in the 1960s purchased gallons of gas, packs of cigarettes, meals,
I mean look at the US Senate Dining Room Restaurant menu I have autographed by Speaker McCormick and Senator Eagleton and Congressman Hungate was on House Judiciary and voyed to impeach Nixon,
Navy Bean Soup 25c
Rib-eye steak $2.50
Coffee 10 c So  while inflation is certain to occur in the short run and the long run not possible for EU in this time frame
Negative demand shock + global recession + misplaced faith in QE -> continued subdued levels of inflation.
Going back to a nice soft round number. Commerce will all but stop, recovery maybe slow as every country will have their own plan and timeline.
Lowering due to expected aftermath of COVID-19 pandemic.

Interesting article on the effect of the Coronavirus on inflation [1] - arguing that it might actually lead to higher inflation. Even if we see this effect based on assumed supply shortages, I'm not sure if we see it as soon as December 2020. Uncertainty around the Coronavirus outbreak remains high so I'm not confident enough to bet on such a scenario. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/mar/03/a-coronavirus-recession-could-be-supply-side-with-a-1970s-flavour
I cannot imagine an inflationary scenario in the current climate of slowing commerce, lock downs, and reduced travel and low oil prices. But I have been wrong before.
Inflation should remain subdued barring unforeseen jump in energy prices. Will be coming off low base in Q4 though providing support for YoY rate.

I am in violent agreement with @Nick-Clark analysis. I am moving off zero, just because its a long time to be hung out there if the unexpected happens.
I chose 2% in sympathy with the question....no other reason. :-) With low oil price, general low demand for travel, some businesses could struggle. Hardly an inflationary environment. Any production shortages will likely be met with reduced demand. Ideally, commerce will return to normal if summer brings a respite from Covid-19 infections.
Unlikely due to potential economic slowdown and no real growth in demand, especially with an increase in probability that countries will tighten boarders to immigration from outside EU countries.

At a late stage in the global business cycle, with the U.S. yield curve inverted (10yr minus 6 months), while central bankers still just don't get that QE leads to asset price inflation - not consumer price inflation and Europe largest economy at 0.6% for 2019, this is simply not going to happen.
too many macro factors moving too quickly to call it anything other than a coin flip right now.
I believe it will 2 and maybe below for both Nov 2020 and Dec 2020
A small chance that Brexit will have unexpected consequences all around. Also if Brexit proves to smooth and economically low-cost other nationalists parties in Europe may agitate to follow suit.
Adjusting due to evidence in top comments, and crowd forcast.

For any month between and including October 2019 and December 2020, will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 2.0%?
With little demand from China for the month of February it would appear that demand for EU goods there would stall in Q1, this could ripple thru the EU in Q2.
With Brent sliding due to reduced demand, inflation should remain in check for 1H2020. Brexit's full impact likely will be felt in 2020 further depressing investment.

For any month between and including October 2019 and December 2020, will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 2.0%?
Hattip @Tetbury for a well reasoned analysis citing ECB data. If the ECB relaxes it grip on inflation tools in the coming months or subtly changes its measurement techniques inflation as reported could expand to better match that experienced on the ground. Unitl then I'll hide in the shadow.

For any month between and including October 2019 and December 2020, will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 2.0%?
IMF says global economy is slowing. Oil may rise due to conflicts, but otherwise, there are no drivers.

There is going to be a lot of chaos with the UK leaving the EU.   This will leave Germany and France bearing the burden of monetizing the negative interest rate targets.  I don't think the payment the UK will have to make for leaving will come in this year.  They only finished paying their WWII debt recently.

The inflation projections for this period produced by the European Central Bank (ECB) in December 2019 consist of a central projection percentage for each month and an upper figure and a lower figure based on  deviations between forecast and actual inflation figures over a number of years. In order to get "Yes" to this question the ECB projections would need to be out by a bigger margin that has happened in the past, Clearly the ECB being more wrong in their projections by a larger  amount than they have in past is a possibility, but very unlikely.
It has been under and the economy is softening. Germany is slowing down in manufacturing.

From the Economist 
“inflation in the euro area reached a six-month high in December. Consumer prices rose by 1.3% year-on-year, up from 1% the previous month. This adds to evidence that the bloc’s economy is stabilising: worried that sluggish inflation signified deeper economic troubles, the European Central Bank cut interest rates last year.”

Took into account the statistical rates of the past 10 years, as well as the recent events past 2017 with the Brexit and the uncertainty it brought with it. Source: https://www.rateinflation.com/inflation-rate/euro-area-historical-inflation-rate
Another source for 1992-2020: https://www.inflation.eu/inflation-rates/europe/historic-inflation/hicp-inflation-europe.aspx The trend as well as the average says we should see values for 2020 around 1%, with a variation around +0.5%/-0.3%.  Brexit will have a direct impact only after the 31st of Dec (which might as well be a deflation due to reducing the actual money supply available on the market). On the "dark side" there are the social unrest movements started for economical reasons in various EU countries, depending on how those would be resolved (or not) leads me to allocate a chance of inflation going past the 2% mark. The feature enlargement of EU regarding Turkey and the Western Balkan states of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and Serbia is not about to happen in 2020, small odds, except maybe Montenegro, but the impact it would have would be less than what we saw for the years when Euro was introduced or when Romania, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Malta, Slovakia etc. joined.
Adjusting based on review of arguments and sources from top comments.
Initial guess based off crowd and existing knowledge.

Base rate given last 5 years: 40% with one close call on both sides.
Modelling the monthly increments as iid normals with zero mean and std=0.28 (using data from the last 12 years), gives me a probability of around 25% starting with 1.0% in november.
I give twice as much weight to the second model, as it is more detailed and is closer to the crowd. 0.66*25+0.34*0.4 = 0.3

If stimulus packages are passed then there is a fair by that I mean 33% chance that inflation will rise above 2% but unlikely as I don't give a more than 33% chance that a stimulus plan would be passed by the european governments
I have stopped explaining my reasoning because daveinsea has been stalking me and flagging my comments because he doesn't like the presentation.

Adjusting down to incorporate the ECB survey of professional estimate. They are predicting a roughly 10% probability of 2020 inflation exceeding 2%. I’m raising that slightly because the question just required one of the next 13 months to be above

Adjusting down due to apparent lack of credibility the ECB has to impact inflation with monetary policy. Rates can’t go much lower and fiscal stimulus seems unlikely given Germany is the only country with sufficient capacity though they lack the willingness.
It’s got a long way to go, but there are also a lot of uncertainties, so it could happen.
If the inflation rate exceeds 2.0 then my bank will lose money on my fixed rate mortgage. I doubt the bank would have offered me that mortgage if their analysts saw a high chance of this happening.
Germany barely avoiding recession (0,1% growth).  Inflation will continue to be low (lower than policy makers would like).

Adjusting up from 5% after I’ve had some more time to think about this one. To be honest, I’m actually a bit surprised the consensus is so low. I calculated the union probability to determine p(inflation =< 2% in any one of the next 15 months). Here is a link on how to calculate it (https://www.thoughtco.com/probability-union-of-three-sets-more-3126263). Doing it for 15 periods is quite tedious, but you do get convergence with really low probabilities. I found that if you assume the probability of inflation reaching or exceeding 2% in any given month is only 1%, then you’d assign a 13% probability for it happening in any one of the next 15 months.  Over the past 10 years inflation has reached or exceeded 2% in 25% of the months. The most recent time it occurred was October, 2018. As a result, my base rate for any given month is 25%. From there, the factors I mentioned in previous posts give me pause on the long-terms strength of the EU economy and the CBs ability to generate inflation. Even if I assume a 5% chance of inflation meeting or exceeding 2% in any given month, my probability that the same condition will be met at least once between now and Dec, 2020 is 45%. We’ll see how data continues to revolve and what steps the Central Bank and governments take to stimulate demand.
Lowering slightly based on the passage of time. I need to take a closer look at the data on this one.

For any month between and including October 2019 and December 2020, will the annual rate of inflation for the eurozone reach or exceed 2.0%? Lots of good arguements. The most likely driver would be an oil shock that would accelerate inflation to the target, but today oil looks overly abundant. It is difficult to see how shocks from Greece or Italy or Spain would drive inflation. Political collapse in a major EU country could force a monetary panic - but I cannot imagine from where. Black swan events are by nature unpredictable and rare. I'll side with the consensus.

The eurozone last hit 2% October 2018, the last month in a five month stretch. In 2019 the closest its come was 1.7% in April so its been a while and that makes it unlikely. However, the monthly number moves a lot so I wouldn't be surprised if it hit 2.0% for a month in one of the next 14 months.

I'll revise to 0 % probality at present. If circumstances change, I'll adjust accordingly; however, markets are forecasting inflation at 5 years at 1.7 to 1.9. My inside view, it will take QE/stimulus measures to be scaled up globally; parallel to resolution of significant trade disputes and Government surplases to be reinvested. All or some of these transpiring before December 2020, not probable.
The 1 year trend is downwards (data based on eurostat) and as of September it hovers around 1%.
No possible way for the ECB to reach it's goal within the next 14 months

Well the consenus is pessimistic at 2% chance of any one month popping to or exceeding 2%. The ECB has 1-2 year ahead 1.2-1.4% inflation annualized. Based on IBCI (ishares Euro gov't linked inflation bond etf), the nominal yield is .12% and real yield -.72%, implying an inflation rate of .84%. I also forsee a slowing of the economy and possible recession which will put downward pressure on inflation. But I count 8 occurrences since Jan 2014 (11.59% of the time), so there is a base case for it to happen. Granted most of these occurred in 2018 and it has been trending downward since then. With 15 months of data points to go, to say that it is a cumulative probability of on 2% of inflation hitting 2% or higher seems overconfident on the downside. I am bearish but that seems extremem, so I would put it at 3-7%.

QE does not boost inflation. We are at the late stage of the business cycle. Both suggest that higher inflation are not in the cards.  Eurostats CPI inflation numbers have been trending downwards in recent months. As others have noted a potential supply chock is the joker. In short, highly unlikely, but possible.

I am the outlier. 15 months is a long time.  So to go immediately 0 is to discount any possibility.  The US Federal Reserve will definitely cut interest rate jn october and maybe 2 more times before june 2020. That will ease emerging markets which will drive demand.  ECB is embarking on QE so it is pursuing loose money.  There is an ulside potential for inflation in EU.

I'm in agreement with the consensus, low probability of reaching 2 %. The global trend is downward growth, and has been since the 2008 recession. Weak world trade growth, protectionism, and trade wars are contributing factors. Slow growth in the US and China would be analogous to the EU. I'll add my probability/start analyse later.

Reflecting low economic growth expectations (see e.g. IMF forecast mentioned in the FT article). Also, the ECB itself seems to have extended its policy timeline in anticipation that the inflation target will take longer to achieve: https://www.politico.eu/article/mario-draghis-parting-gift-to-the-eurozone/
There is always the possibility of a supply-side shock, but very low probability.
Damnit.  Forgot to look at crowd first.  Fools bet, it turns out Only energy or war drives this to 2%

Negative interest rates and a global slowdown will keep inflation low despite QE and consistently lower interest rates in the EU. I’ll continue to research forward guidance, but large scale fiscal stimulus will be needed to drive inflation. Given disparate economies across the EU, this seems less likely than it would in any one country.

Highly unlikely due to deflationary trend, negative interest rates in Germany, uncertainty surrounding Souther European economies and Brexit. Will follow up with a statistical analysis but I am putting in an early forecast in the name of accuracy points. A reason I am not going to 0 for now, among others is: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cromwell%27s_rule
THey wish. Negative interest rates tell the story.
